data.title: 100 Best Famous French Movies of All Time, Ranked
data.meta_description: From Malle to Melville, Carn√© to Clouzot, this is Time Out‚Äôs ultimate guide to the best French movies ever released.
data.text:
In the popular imagination, ‚ÄòFrench‚Äô is often used as a euphemism for pretentiousness, and that‚Äôs especially true for its movies. For mainstream audiences, the country‚Äôs films are painfully stylish, achingly cool and totally impenetrable, laden with philosophy, avant-garde structures and emotionally unreadable characters. It‚Äôs not entirely untrue: after all, pioneering New Wavers like Jean-Luc Godard and Agn√®s Varda prided themselves on confounding viewers. But the truth is, few countries can claim to have exerted as strong and consistent an influence over global moviemaking as France. Once you start digging into the history of French film, though, you‚Äôll discover pleasures unlike those found anywhere else in world cinema.

Admittedly, though, knowing where to start can be difficult. Consider this your tourist pamphlet. On this list of the 100 best French films of all-time, you‚Äôll find everything from well-known crowd-pleasers like Am√©lie and Criterion-canonised classics to obscure gems sure to challenge even deep-diving Nouvelle Vague obsessives. No matter your experience level, you‚Äôre sure to discover something surprising.

Written by Tom Huddleston, Geoff Andrew, Dave Calhoun, Cath Clarke, Trevor Johnston, Joshua Rothkopf, Keith Uhlich and Matthew Singer

Director: Marcel Carn√©

In Marcel Carn√©‚Äôs rich, literary romance from 1945 (‚ÄòFrance‚Äôs answer to ‚ÄúGone with the Wind‚Äù!‚Äô), four men tussle for the affections of one woman, the conflicted, sphinx-like Garence (Carn√© regular Arletty), an ice maiden in the league of Marlene Dietrich who, in nearly every shot, has her eyes masked by a beam of light. Such ethereal, delicately cinematic touches add to a film which is content to let a dazzling, witty script (by Jacques Pr√©vert), sumptuous set design and exceptional performers lend the fiction its lifeblood. DJ

Director: Jean Renoir

Banned on its original release as ‚Äòtoo demoralising‚Äô, and only made available again in its original form in 1956, Renoir‚Äôs brilliant social comedy is epitomised by the phrase ‚Äòeveryone has their reasons‚Äô. Centreing on a lavish country house party given by the Marquis de la Chesnaye and his wife (Dalio, Gregor), the film effects audacious slides from melodrama into farce, from realism into fantasy, and from comedy into tragedy. Romantic intrigues, social rivalries, and human foibles are all observed with an unblinking eye that nevertheless refuses to judge. The carnage of the rabbit shoot, the intimations of mortality introduced by the after-dinner entertainment, and Renoir‚Äôs own performance are all unforgettable. Embracing every level of French society, from the aristocratic hosts to a poacher-turned-servant, the film presents a hilarious yet melancholy picture of a nation riven by petty class distinctions. NF

Advertising

Director: Carl Theodor Dreyer

Dreyer‚Äôs most universally acclaimed masterpiece remains one of the most staggeringly intense films ever made. It deals only with the final stages of Joan‚Äôs trial and her execution and is composed almost exclusively of close-ups: hands, robes, crosses, metal bars, and (most of all) faces. The face we see most is, naturally, Falconetti‚Äôs as Joan, and it‚Äôs hard to imagine a performer evincing physical anguish and spiritual exaltation more palpably. Dreyer encloses this stark, infinitely expressive face with other characters and sets that are equally devoid of decoration and equally direct in conveying both material and metaphysical essences. The entire film is less moulded in light than carved in stone: it‚Äôs magisterial cinema, and almost unbearably moving. TR

Director: Jacques Tati

Tati‚Äôs Hulot on the loose in a surreal, scarcely recognisable Paris, tangling intermittently with a troop of friendly American matrons on a 24-hour trip. Not so much a saga of the individual against an increasingly dehumanised d√©cor, it‚Äôs more a semi-celebratory symphony to Tati‚Äôs sensational city set, all reflections and rectangles, steel, chrome, gleaming sheet metal and trompe-l‚Äôoeil plate glass. Shot in colour that looks almost like monochrome, recorded in five-track stereo sound with scarcely a word of speech (the mysterious language of objects echoes louder than words), this jewel of Tati‚Äôs career is a hallucinatory comic vision on the verge of abstraction. SJO

Advertising

Director: Jean-Luc Godard

Le m√©pris. That‚Äôs ‚Äòcontempt‚Äô in French, and that‚Äôs the feeling Camille (Brigitte Bardot) increasingly has for her writer boyfriend Paul (Michel Piccoli) during the time he‚Äôs summoned to Rome‚Äôs Cinecitt√† film studios and the stunning island of Capri to help Austrian-born Hollywood director Fritz Lang (playing himself) and coarse American producer Prokosch (Jack Palance) improve their movie version of Homer‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Odyssey‚Äô. Much of the film gives us Camille and Paul‚Äôs disintegrating relationship as he‚Äôs simultaneously seduced and repelled by the world of filmmaking. It shows Godard and his collaborators ‚Äì especially cinematographer Raoul Coutard, composer Georges Delerue and editor Agn√®s Guillemot ‚Äì at the height of their powers, creating scenes and moments of extraordinary visual power, suggestion and beauty. Like Camille and Paul‚Äôs love-hate relationship, it‚Äôs the ultimate testament to Godard‚Äôs complicated relationship with his art. DC

Director: Jean-Pierre Jeunet

Arguably the quintessential subtitled film for people who don‚Äôt like subtitled films (it‚Äôd be a dust-up between this and ‚ÄòCinema Paradiso‚Äô), Jean-Pierre Jeunet‚Äôs rose-tinted Parisian romance is likely to be the role for which actress Audrey Tautou will be remembered until her dying day. The film is all the more interesting for remaining an eccentric one-of-a-kind that feels every bit the product of its writer-director‚Äôs unique sensibility and worldview. Revisiting it now, it still has the same strengths: the experience of watching is like being swept along on a tidal wave of cheeky jokes and oddball observations. DJ

Advertising

Director: Jean Vigo

1934‚Äôs ‚ÄòL‚ÄôAtalante‚Äô is the single feature from the then 29-year-old French master Jean Vigo and was made as its director died of TB. The result is not so much a film as an entire artistic vision crammed into 89 of the busiest and most beautiful minutes of celluloid ever shot. Dita Parlo plays Juliette, the smalltown girl married off to Jean (Jean Dast√©), captain of L‚ÄôAtalante, a grubby barge plying the waterways of rural France. Once on board, Juliette is caught between her uncertain love for Jean and her desire to see a world beyond the restrictive confines of the boat. The situation is complicated by the constant interruptions of Jean‚Äôs beloved but irascible first mate P√©re Jules (Michel Simon). The result is something utterly indescribable, partway between comedy and tragedy, romance and realism, film and dream. TH

Director: Agn√®s Varda

‚ÄòCl√©o from 5 to 7‚Äô (1962) was French new waver Agn√®s Varda‚Äôs second feature and is filled with the beauty of Paris‚Äôs natural light. ‚ÄòHold on, pretty butterfly!‚Äô says Cl√©o (Corinne Marchand), a fretful and fame-occupied singer, to herself as she prepares to roam the city for two hours while awaiting a possibly momentous doctor‚Äôs verdict. It‚Äôs experimental and free-wheeling in design ‚Äì Varda gives us overlapping dialogue, parodic inserts, a documentarist‚Äôs eye mixed with a painter‚Äôs, found sound and Michel Legrand‚Äôs songs, and juxtaposes frippery with political reality. Quietly touching and profound, it epitomises the youthful delight Varda always shows for the tools at her disposal and her sensitive and easeful way of expressing the sways and shifts of life, love and desire. WH

Advertising

Director: Fran√ßois Truffaut

In 1959 Fran√ßois Truffaut, neglected son, passionate reader, delinquent student and cinephile, wrote and filmed one of the first glistening droplets of the French New Wave, ‚ÄòThe 400 Blows‚Äô, in which Antoine Doinel (Jean-Pierre L√©aud) demonstrates ‚Äì unforgettably ‚Äì that a good brain and bad parents don‚Äôt necessarily turn a boy into a talented film director, although they will, one way or another, turn him into a liar. Antoine is an inept thief who winds up incarcerated; somehow, Truffaut turned this saga into one of the most joyous experiences you could ever have in the cinema. The beauty of monochrome ‚Äô50s Paris helps, but the magic is in observing the thrill even a maltreated child will snatch from a book, a film or a day truanting at a funfair, through the gaze of a former critic whose elation at getting his hands on a camera burbles through every shot. NC

Director: Jean Cocteau

A gorgeous, pin-sharp remaster for poet-dramatist-artist-director Jean Cocteau‚Äôs giddy, sumptuous 1946 retelling of the Freudian fairytale about a helpless girl and a kindhearted monster. Slightly pompous preamble aside, this ‚ÄòBeauty and the Beast‚Äô is pure joy, a self-conscious but never precious attempt to revisit childhood fantasies and half-remembered dreams. The Beast‚Äôs ornate, decaying castle ‚Äì ringed with thorns and filled with grasping hands ‚Äì is a place of terror, wonder and mourning, the perfect reflection of its tragic, noble occupant. The tug of love between the monster and the maiden is never overplayed, but neither does the film shackle this beast ‚Äì he remains unpredictable and threatening throughout. It has been accused of valuing style over substance, but place the film in its historical context and its true intent is revealed: in the wake of unimaginable horror, this kind of fantasy is still achievable, and perhaps more important than ever. TH

Advertising

Director: Jean-Pierre Melville

You couldn‚Äôt imagine a more discreet tribute to the heroes of the wartime French Resistance than this terrific late-‚Äô60s thriller by the ex-Maquis member Melville, the director best known for his gangster masterpieces like ‚ÄòThe Samourai‚Äô. Tracing the self-sacrificial exploits from October 1942 to February 1943 of a small group of field operatives ‚Äì the acerbic Lino Ventura‚Äôs ex-engineer, Simone Signoret‚Äôs iron-nerved Mathilde among them ‚Äì Melville‚Äôs film adopts a formal essentialism to outline the codes and manners of impassive-looking ‚Äòwarriors‚Äô over whom the Damocles sword of discovery, torture and death is ever hovering. The film boasts a startling visual quality, too ‚Äì the suspenseful twilight escapades are shot with a beautifully muted, steely-grey colour palette by cinematographer Pierre Lhomme ‚Äì and it is laced with moments of dry, sardonic wit that serve only to emphasise its devastating emotional core even more. Superb. WH

Director: Fran√ßois Truffaut

‚ÄòDay for Night‚Äô is hilarious and informative, and in the pantheon of films about filmmaking, it strikes a neat balance between the operatic neuroses of ‚Äò8 1/2‚Äô and the warm, pastel-hued nostalgia of ‚ÄòSingin‚Äô in the Rain‚Äô. Truffaut stars as indefatigable director Ferrand, shooting a fusty melodrama called ‚ÄòMeet Pamela‚Äô and wearing the same sports jacket, shirt and tie combo as he would in ‚ÄòClose Encounters of the Third Kind‚Äô. He delivers the same coolly detached performance, too, though it works better in this context. The fact that his childish lead (Jean-Pierre L√©aud, of course) is too often in a strop to concentrate on the part, or that his star (Jacqueline Bisset) is a woman on the verge of a nervous breakdown are accepted as part and parcel of the business. DJ

Advertising

Director: Jacques Demy

Jacques Demy‚Äôs pastel-hued masterpiece ‚ÄòLes Demoiselles de Rochefort‚Äô is a luminous musical about dreams, romance and destiny which lovingly reworks the classic Hollywood ‚Äòputting on a show‚Äô template into an essay on the emotional rollercoaster ride that is movie-going. Released here in a sparkling new print, the film centres on Catherine Deneuve and Fran√ßoise Dorl√©ac as the ‚Äòpair of twins, born in the sign of Gemini‚Äô looking to escape the sleepy environs of Rochefort for life in the big city. When an all-singin‚Äô, all-dancin‚Äô motorcycle roadshow rolls into town, the girls decide to give one last big performance before upping sticks and moving on. Most will be swept off their feet by Michel Legrand‚Äôs scintillating jazz-pop score, charismatic supporting turns from Gene Kelly, Danielle Darrieux and Michel Piccoli, and ‚Äì predominantly ‚Äì Demy‚Äôs own infectious joie de vivre. DJ

Director: Henri-Georges Clouzot

Throughout his professional life, France‚Äôs Henri-Georges Clouzot suffered comparisons to Alfred Hitchcock ‚Äì the former's critical reputation languished for it, and he took it hard. Clouzot needn‚Äôt have worried: on a good day, he was arguably better. ‚ÄòLes Diaboliques‚Äô (1955) is the perfect psychosexual thriller, and this earlier effort is Hitch‚Äôs bomb-under-the-table suspense formula burnished to an expert sheen. Literally explosive, the plot concerns a South American oil fire raging out of control, with only the possibility of a nitroglycerine blast to snuff it out. But which poor schmucks will transport the combustible jerricans over miles of bumpy road to the site? Clouzot‚Äôs entire body of work deserves to be revisited, but ‚ÄòThe Wages of Fear‚Äô is ground zero and undoubtedly the place to start. JR

Advertising

Director: Jacques Tati

Tati‚Äôs first film in colour. Yes, his contrast of the glorious awfulness of the Arpels‚Äô automated modernistic house with Hulot‚Äôs disordered bohemianism is simplistic. Yes, Hulot as champion of the individual is oddly de-personalised. And one might even conclude that Tati is a closet misanthrope. Such text-book reservations come and go as this extraordinary film meanders like the Arpels‚Äô concrete garden path. But while some episodes are protracted, many are unforgettably funny, wonderfully observed, and always technically brilliant. Insane gadgets slam and roar, high heels click like metronomes, and even a depressed dachshund in a tartan overcoat obligingly submits to Tati‚Äôs meticulous direction. TS

Director: Jean-Luc Godard

What‚Äôs cooler than being cool? Well, Jean-Luc Godard‚Äôs first feature is pretty dang ice-cold, an exercise in style-is-substance that didn‚Äôt necessarily launch the Nouvelle Vague but ended up defining it. Narratively, it‚Äôs a threadbare crime drama about a Parisian thief (Jean-Paul Belmondo) on the run for shooting a police officer who still finds time to fall in love with an American newspaper girl (Jean Seberg). But the plot is really just an excuse to watch two incredibly beautiful people hang out in one of the world‚Äôs most beautiful cities. That‚Äôs enough to make it utterly entrancing, but what made it groundbreaking were Godard‚Äôs flights of directorial fancy: the unconventional jump cuts, improvised dialogue, the score blending classical music with French pop. It revolutionised French cinema ‚Äì and later Hollywood ‚Äì but with an air of iconoclastic insouciance that, of course, made it even cooler.

Advertising

Director: Fran√ßois Truffaut

In 1962, Truffaut released an adaptation of Henri-Pierre Roch√©‚Äôs novel ‚ÄòJules et Jim‚Äô. It was Fran√ßois Truffaut‚Äôs third feature film, but this one was special: the young tyro director and the art collector from another era (Roch√© had died in 1959, aged 80) came together like, well, Jules and Jim. Roche‚Äôs autobiographical story of a Frenchman, Jim (Henri Serre) and a German, Jules (Oskar Werner) whose friendship survives the First World War and their adoration of the same woman, Catherine (Jeanne Moreau) becomes, in Truffaut‚Äôs hands, a paean to passion and an ineffably elegant classic. The filmmaking is wildly inventive, but not in a clever-clogs manner. Instead, Truffaut and his cinematographer, the great Raoul Coutard, use handheld camera, freeze-frames, newsreel footage and song in the same way the characters use races, bicycle trips or impromptu jumps into the Seine: to keep life (and cinema) crazy and beautiful at all times. NC

Director: Michael Haneke

Michael Haneke‚Äôs ‚ÄòAmour‚Äô is a devastatingly original and unflinching look at the effect of love on death, and vice versa. It‚Äôs a staggering, intensely moving reflection on old age and life‚Äôs end, which at its heart offers two performances of incredible skill and wisdom from French veterans Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva. The director of ‚ÄòHidden‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe White Ribbon‚Äô offers an intimate and brave portrait of an elderly Parisian couple, Anne (Riva) and Georges (Trintignant), facing up to a sudden turning point in their lives. Haneke erects four walls to keep out the rest of the world, contained almost entirely within one apartment over a period of some weeks and months. He asks hard questions and creates a highly intelligent and astonishingly performed work. DC

Advertising

Director: Robert Bresson

Animal as saint: Bresson‚Äôs stark, enigmatic parable, a donkey (named after one of the Three Wise Men) is both a witness to and the victim of mankind‚Äôs cruelty, stupidity ‚Äì and love. Taking his lack of faith in theatrical acting to its logical limit, Bresson perversely places the mute beast centre-screen as he passes from owner to owner, giving rides, heaving agricultural machinery, and receiving beatings and caresses in a coolly observed landscape of poverty and folly. The effect could not be more different from that of other films (Disney‚Äôs say, or ‚ÄòJaws‚Äô) that centre around animals; Balthazar‚Äôs death during a smuggling expedition, amid a field of sheep, is both lyrical and entirely devoid of maudlin sentiment. Imbued with a dry, ironic sense of humour, the film is perhaps the director‚Äôs most perfectly realised, and certainly his most moving. GA

Director: Jacques Audiard

For Jacques Audiard (‚ÄòA Self-Made Hero‚Äô, ‚ÄòThe Beat That My Heart Skipped‚Äô), a master of the old-school French thriller, his fifth film offers the chance to pull off both a state-of-the-nation primal scream and a terrific crime flick. He gives us Malik (Tahar Rahim), a French-Arab convict who enters a concrete-and-steel hell to serve a six-year sentence. Corsican inmates rule the roost, led by ageing but vicious C√©sar (Niels Arestrup), who forces Malik to kill another inmate in an exceedingly disturbing episode. Malik is now C√©sar‚Äôs vassal, working for him on the inside and, later, using a series of day-release excursions to represent his criminal interests on the outside. But Malik is a clever individualist and he learns to read and write, and exploits a friendship with another (released) French-Arab prisoner to pursue his own drug deals and invest in a power base within the jail. It bullies and persuades you to love Audiard‚Äôs filmmaking style. DC

Advertising

Director: Michael Haneke

A smart marriage of the thriller genre with a compendium of strong ideas about guilt, racism, recent French history and cinema itself, Michael Haneke‚Äôs eighth feature is an unsettling, self-reflective masterpiece. Georges and Anne Laurent (Daniel Auteuil and Juliette Binoche) are a wealthy middle-class couple who are ostensibly paragons of the Parisian intelligentsia. We watch as the pair agonise over sinister CCTV sent anonymously to their apartment. For the Laurents, it‚Äôs the start of a horrific upset that mirrors the disturbing breakdown of familial comfort that characterised Haneke‚Äôs ‚ÄòFunny Games‚Äô, ‚ÄòTime of the Wolf‚Äô and ‚ÄòBenny‚Äôs Video‚Äô. The tapes and the flashbacks, we are led to believe, are linked and Georges becomes convinced that the videos are connected to an Algerian, Majid. Haneke crafts the fabric and routine of the couple‚Äôs life with cold precision, only to upset their habits violently at regular intervals.

Director: Jean Renoir

As relevant as ever, Jean Renoir‚Äôs 1937 masterpiece ‚ÄòLa Grande Illusion‚Äô is a film about common values and decency ‚Äì the ability in all of us to act with respect and warmth towards those with whom we share bonds stronger and deeper than national boundaries and political divisions. This is an anti-war film, too, of course, made on the eve of one conflict and looking back at another. It concerns three French officers held as prisoners during the First World War by the Germans: aristocratic De Boeldieu (Pierre Fresnay), working-class Mar√©chal (Jean Gabin) and wealthy Jew Rosenthal (Marcel Dalio). The shared purpose of the French is to the fore (one of the film‚Äôs many illusions: we can‚Äôt be sure such unity would persist in peace). DC

Advertising

23. Lift to the Scaffold (1958)

Director: Louis Malle

The great Louis Malle shepherds all the elements of a great thriller into an endlessly entertaining, quickfire 88 minutes in this juicy Parisian noir. It‚Äôs satisfying on just about every level: from its grasping, murderous schemers (played by Jeanne Moreau and Maurice Ronet) to its plot that twists and turns in all sorts of deliriously tricksy ways. Then, there‚Äôs that classic Miles Davis score, recorded in only two days while the musician was visiting Paris. It brings the film‚Äôs existential, melancholy mood to life like few thrillers before or since, and makes Malle‚Äôs gem of a film a must-hear as well as a must-see. PDS

24. Wooden Crosses (1932)

Director: Raymond Bernard

If you associate Champagne with fizzy wines and grand ch√¢teaux, this underseen and seriously underrated First World War drama will add a new dimension to the region. Here, it‚Äôs the setting for endless struggle in the trenches in a film that brings the French soldiers to salty, stoical life. The battle scenes ‚Äì including one lengthy nocturnal skirmish in a French town ‚Äì rival anything from more heralded war movies like ‚ÄòAll Quiet on the Western Front‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe Big Parade‚Äô, yet this film is an emotional as well as technical triumph. One of France‚Äôs lesser-known greats, director Raymond Bernard would go on to make an acclaimed five-hour version of ‚ÄòLes Mis√©rables‚Äô, but this is his masterpiece. PDS

Advertising

Director: Christophe Barratier

Mild-mannered, unemployed music teacher Clement Mathieu is hired as a house master at the Fond de l‚ÄôEtang boarding school for troubled children. From the moment Clement walks through the school gates, he can sense trouble, much of it perpetrated by the repressive headmaster Rachin, who believes that physical punishment is the only way to keep the boys in line. Clement prefers a much more caring approach to schooling and he introduces his pint-sized pupils to the magic of singing.

26. Les Mis√©rables (2019)

Director: Ladj Ly

On the one hand, that French-Malian director Ladj Ly‚Äôs crunching cops-and-criminals drama feels like a spiritual successor to ‚ÄòLa Haine‚Äô shows, worryingly, how little has changed in Paris‚Äôs simmering banlieues in 25 years. On the other‚Ä¶ well, it‚Äôs not a bad film to be compared with. Like Mathieu Kassovitz‚Äôs visceral 1995 drama, Ly offers unsettling social commentary in his fully sketched ensemble of strivers, schemers and seething migrants. But he adds genre thrills to excellent effect, too, as well as the odd semi-surreal touch (the plot revolves around a missing lion cub). Don‚Äôt be surprised if we‚Äôre still referencing this one in 25 years. PDS

Advertising

Director: Maurice Pialat

This stunningly photographed and skilfully acted film uses an accretion of naturalistic detail to present an emotionally restrained but utterly compelling account of the last three months of van Gogh‚Äôs life. Living in Auvers-sur-Oise with his sensitive and knowledgeable patron Gachet (Sety), van Gogh (Dutronc) works quietly and steadily, meanwhile flirting with Gachet‚Äôs precocious daughter Marguerite (London). However, his ill health, a brief return to the debauchery of brothels and drink, and his irrational resentment of his brother Theo‚Äôs failure to sell his work, provoke erratic swings from brooding introspection to frustrated anger. There‚Äôs no attempt to trace the origins and development of his ‚Äòcreative genius‚Äô; nor, avoiding the hazards of biopic clich√©, does it seek to illuminate these dark corners of his subject‚Äôs troubled soul. In the leading role, Dutronc displays a physical frailty and stooped sadness that complements Pialat‚Äôs beautiful, poignant images. NF

Director: Jean-Luc Godard

Jean-Paul Belmondo mooches up to Samuel Fuller at a party and, naturally, asks him his thoughts on cinema. Fuller replies: ‚ÄòFilm is like a battleground. Love. Hate. Action. Violence. Death. In one word: Emotions.‚Äô His succinct and, let‚Äôs be honest, utterly hip rejoinder fluently captures what we‚Äôre about to undergo with Godard‚Äôs mischievous tenth film, ‚ÄòPierrot le Fou‚Äô. We‚Äôre launched into the lunatic orbit of Belmondo‚Äôs Ferdinand and Anna Karina‚Äôs Marianne: Each is an impulsive, alienated, despairing soul who finds solace in the other‚Äôs desire for chaos and withdrawal. They head to the south of France in a hail of gunfire and Gauloises. They converse in disjointed, inhumanly droll patter, duff up gas station attendants and eagerly concoct a new civilisation on a deserted beach. As their relationship begins to fray, it all goes horribly wrong. This is a wild-eyed cross-processing of artistic, political and personal concerns, with a story that stutters, splinters and infuriates its way to an explosive finale. DJ

Advertising

29. 120 Beats per Minute (2017)

Director: Robin Campillo

Have we talked about this film enough? In a time of intolerance, protest and fevered passions, Robin Campillo‚Äôs glorious, moving memoir of his time in Aids activism group Act Up in ‚Äô90s Paris captures a sense of recurring zeitgeist: just swap in Extinction Rebellion to see how its story of politically engaged young people fearing for their futures still resonates. But there‚Äôs a specificity to these characters and this story, too: its incensed, impassioned and hedonistic ensemble feel real; their fears are scary and relatable. But as the title implies, Campillo‚Äôs film takes to the dance floor to shake them loose in a flurry of loose limbs and free spirits. A film about the threat of death has never felt so alive. PDS

Director: Bertrand Blier

Rigorously absurd contemporary film noir which presents every character, incident and situation known to the genre, but none of the customary explanations, motivations or consequences. A blackly surreal procession of amoral and/or illegal acts proceed haphazardly from Depardieu‚Äôs discovery of his lost penknife embedded in a dying metro traveller, and his subsequent alliance with his wife‚Äôs murderer and a police inspector, producing a cherishably Bu√±uelian depiction of the far-from-discreet crimes of the bourgeoisie. PT

Advertising

Director: Alain Resnais

Something of a key film in the development of concepts of cinematic modernism, simply because ‚Äì with a script by nouveau roman iconoclast Alain Robbe-Grillet ‚Äì it sets up a puzzle that is never resolved: a man meets a woman in a rambling hotel and believes he may have had an affair with her the previous year at Marienbad... or did he? Or was it somewhere else? Deliberately scrambling chronology to the point where past, present and future become meaningless, Resnais creates a vaguely unsettling mood by means of stylish composition, long, smooth tracking shots along the hotel‚Äôs deserted corridors, and strangely detached performances. GA

Director: Abdellatif Kechiche

‚ÄòBlue is the Warmest Colour‚Äô is a minutely detailed, searingly erotic three-hour study of first lesbian love. Written and directed by the French-Tunisian Abdellatif Kechiche, it is the richest film of his career. Nothing about the film‚Äôs coming-of-age narrative, nor the rise and fall of its core romance, is intrinsically new or daring, yet Kechiche‚Äôs freewheeling perspective on young desire is uncommon in its emotional maturity. Our heroine, Ad√®le (Ad√®le Exarchopoulos, astonishing), begins the film as a precocious high-schooler and ends as a grown woman still with plenty to learn about herself. Unlike so many same-sex-themed films that focus on coming out as the defining gay experience, ‚ÄòBlue is the Warmest Colour‚Äô glides past that stage of Ad√®le‚Äôs life in a bold chronological leap, finding more nuanced drama in the evolving challenges of maintaining an unfixed sexuality. GL

Advertising

Director: Jean-Pierre Melville

Melville‚Äôs hombres don‚Äôt talk a lot, they just move in and out of the shadows, their trenchcoats lined with guilt and their hats hiding their eyes. This is a great movie, an austere masterpiece, with Delon as a cold, enigmatic contract killer who lives by a personal code of bushido.
